property.name: text
property.value: This demo illustrates the concept analysis capabilities of the ontologies package, applied to the CarTracking model.

property.name: text
property.value: Simulate the driver of the leading car. Output is the driver's desired speed.

property.name: text
property.value: Simulate a car that matches the desired speed using feedback control with a specified time constant.

property.name: text
property.value:
This particular solver defines an ontology and rules for physical type analysis. (For example: The integral of a Velocity is a Speed; trying to add a Time and a Speed produces a Conflict; and more).
To learn more about how the ontology and rules are defined, right click the solver -> Open Model
To run the solver, either run the model or right click -> Resolve Concepts
The display colors for the concepts can also be customized, right click -> Configure -> Concept Display
One use case for ontology resolution is to detect errors in a model. This solver implements some special functionality to help track down and fix errors. 1) First, right click on DriverSimulator -> Open Actor and follow instructions there to create an error 2) Next, come back to this screen, and right click on the solver -> Resolve Concepts to see the conflicts in the model. 3) Finally, right click -> Resolve Conflicts. The solver will try to narrow down the cause of the error. (In this case, you know it, does the solver's conclusion match?)
Additional menu options: Clear Concept Highlighting: Removes the colors, but does not clear the solver's state Clear Concept Resolution: Removes the colors and clears the solver's state Highlight Concepts: Shows colors from an existing resolution, but does not run solver

property.name: text
property.value:
The solver works for parameters and expressions as well as actors.
An AnnotationAttribute allows a user to specify a constraint manually. This is especially useful for parameters.
An AnnotationAttribute has the format: ontologyName::attributeName for its name, where ontologyName is the name of the ontology and attributeName is any name (unique within scope)
object >= Concept for its value, where object is any model object which can have a concept, and Concept is the concept from the ontology
Here, SpeedValue refers to a parameter, and Velocity is a concept in the dimensionSystem ontology.
Ports are another common object used in AnnotationAttributes, for example, Const2.output >= Position

property.name: text
property.value: Car simulator. This model takes as input a desired speed and implements a simple proportional controller with the specified loop gain to achieve that speed. It outputs the acceleration, speed, and position of the car.

property.name: text
property.value: This model outputs the desired speed of a driver that wishes to maintain a nominal speed (55 miles per hour in this case), but superimposes a jitter (plus or minus 30 miles per hour in this case). It thus models a highly irregular driver.

property.name: text
property.value:
To introduce an error, double-click on DimensionSystemSolver::constraint3 and change the second part of the expression to Acceleration: nominalSpeed >= Acceleration
To the solver, this means that the nominalSpeed parameter is at least an Acceleration.
But, this causes a problem. The Add2 actor will try to add an Acceleration (nominalSpeed) and a Velocity (other input). This causes a Conflict, because only inputs of the same concept can be added together.

display.name: Const Nominal Speed in miles per hour
